Naval, Militaryand air operations.(previous reference erence:W.M. (41) 40thConclusions,Minute 1.)Air Operations.naval operations.Shipping Losses.Mediterranean.MilitaryOperations.1. The Chiefs of Staff made the following reports in amplification-cation of Cabinet War Room Records Nos. 590-592.Enemy losses in the attack on London the previous night woreestimated at from 6 to 9 aircraft.There had been a great improvement in the technical efficiency of our night fighters.We had despatched about 100 bombers to Bremen the previous night. One bomber was missing and two had been shot down by enemy fighters operating over this country.Shipping casualties in the last three days had been about,300 tons of shipping lost and about 27,000 tons damaged, mostlyin the Mediterranean.On the previous day four of our destroyers had sunk an enemyconvoy of five merchant vessels (2 M.T. ships, 1 ammunition ship and 2 vessels of 3,000 tons) and three destroyers off the Libyan coast.During this operation H.M. Destroyer Mohawk had been torpedoed and sunk; the Captain, seven officers and 160 ratings had beenrescued.The Military Attache- at Madrid reported that the Franco-Spanish Frontier was closed at Hendaye.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.Balkans and middle East.MilitaryOperations.(previous reference erence:W.M. (41) 40thConclusions,Minute 1.)Iraq.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 40thConclusions,Minute'2.)2. The War Cabinet were informed of the progress of operations in the Balkans and the Middle East. A record of theinformation given, and of the discussion, is contained in theSecretary's Standard File of War Cabinet Conclusions.3. The First Sea Lord said that a telegram had been receivedby one of the naval vessels escorting the troops to Basra, to the effectthat our Ambassador had told Rashid Ali of the impending arrival of troops, and that he had received the news well.The Secretary of State for Foreign A ffairs said that a latertelegram had been received from Sir K. Cornwallis reporting thatRashid Ali had asked that troops should arrive in successive wavesat 24 hours' interval.The War Cabinet took note of this information.Air Raids.Damage.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 38tliConclusions,Minute 2.)Belfast.London.4. The Minister of Home Security gave the following information : On the night of the 15th/16th April there had been a fairlyheavy attack on Belfast, which had caused serious fires.Responsibility for,air-raid matters rested on the Northern ireland government; but steps had been taken to send reinforcements ofpumps and firemen from this country. The Admiralty had taken over pumps and men on a Destroyer: Help had also been receivedfrom Dublin.On the previous night 500 aircraft had been oyer this country,of Which 460 had been concentrated on London. The attack hadbeen widespread, 66 London Boroughs having been affected. Themain weight of the attack had fallen on Central and South London.There had been 40 serious fires, including Lisson Grove goods yard,Selfridges and Kidbrpoke aerodrome. Railways and! roads had.[22429]::s;'2: suffered fairly heavily, but little damage had been done to the docks.Casualties could not at present be estimated. It was known that560 people had been killed, but this number might well be doubled.2,000 seriously injured had so far been reported. Traffic congestionwas serious, and it would probably be necessary to take steps to keepunnecessary traffic off the roads in the areas affected.The First Lord of the A dmiralty reported that the bomb whichhad fallen on the Admiralty Building had destroyed two or threerooms on all the floors down to the ground floor in the South Block,and 100 rooms had been rendered temporarily uninhabitable. TheBoard room had also suffered serious damage. Six people had beeninjured, but none fatally.The War Cabinet took note of this information.Parliament. 5. (41) 84). the division of the Memorandum set out the lines of the Agreement which had beensubmarine reached in principle with the Venezuelan Government for theareas. division of the sea bed, subject to the cession by this country toVenezuela of the Island of Patos.The Secretary of State for the Colonies wished to put it on record that the Governor of Trinidad was not in favour of theAgreement. He (the Secretary of State) and his advisers thoughtthat it was in our interests.The War Cabinet-Approved the conclusion of an Agreement on the lines proposed, and the procedure set out in paragraphs 8 and 9. - of the Memorandum.OverseasCivilianTechnical Corps.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 40thConclusions,Minute 6.)7.- The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theSecretary of State for Air (W.P. (G) (41) 39).The Secretary of State for Air said that the United states authorities thought that they could not permit a public appeal for volunteers for enlistment in an armed force. The present schemewas not quite so attractive from our point of view, but would serve the purpose of obtaining the skilled men required. The next step would be to set up a recruiting organisation in the United States.This would be followed by publicity. The development of thisscheme would, of course, be carried out in consultation with theTreasury. The War Office agreed with it.The War Cabinet-Approved the establishment of an Overseas CivilianTechnical Corps, to be recruited in the United States, onthe lines set out in the Memorandum. CM1 Service.parliamentary candidature ofCivil Servants.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 15thConclusions,Minute 8.)8. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theLord Privy Seal (W.P. (G) (41) 38) on the question whether the rule as to Parliamentary candidature of Civil Servants should be modified so as to enable persons who had already been, or mighthereafter be, adopted as prospective candidates by particularConstituencies, to serve the Crown in a civil capacity temporarilyduring the war. This matter had been examined by the home policy Committee, whose general view was that the present practice in this matter, as set out in the Servants of the Crown(Parliamentary Candidature) Order in Council of 1927, should notbe modified.The War Cabinet Expressed their concurrence in this conclusion.Great George Street, S.W. 1,April 17, 1941.
